description: Number of solutions to Nickerson variant of Langford (or Langford-Skolem) problem.
comments: How many ways are of arranging the numbers 1,1,2,2,3,3,...,n,n so that there are zero numbers between the two 1's, one number between the two 2's, ..., n-1 numbers between the two n's?For n>1, a(n) = A004075(n)/2 because A004075 also counts reflected solutions. - _Martin Fuller_, Mar 08 2007Because of symmetry, is a(5) = 5 the largest prime in this sequence? - _Jonathan Vos Post_, Apr 02 2011
links: Ali Assarpour, Amotz Bar-Noy, Ou Liuo, Counting the Number of Langford Skolem Pairings, arXiv:1507.00315 [cs.DM], 2015.
R. S. Nickerson and D. C. B. Marsh, E1845: A variant of Langford's Problem, American Math. Monthly, 1967, 74, 591-595.
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Feb 14 2001
extensions: Extended using results from the Assarpour et al. (2015) paper by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Feb 22 2016 at the suggestion of _William Rex Marshall_.
